original_title: Sri Lankan banks, conglomerates hold ground despite weak country credit profile, says Fitch Ratings
original_body_lines: Fitch Ratings’ latest update on Sri Lanka’s credit landscape shows that the country’s leading commercial banks and well- managed conglomerates continue to hold stable national ratings despite the weak record of the government’s credit metrics.

As at 31 August 2025, Commercial Bank of Ceylon, Hatton National Bank, Sampath Bank, and People’s Bank retained investment-grade national ratings between AA-(lka) and A(lka) with stable outlooks. This reflects sound capital adequacy and stable deposit franchises despite a tough operating environment. Union Bank of Colombo remains an outlier with a BBB-(lka) rating on a negative outlook, while Cargills Bank was affirmed at A(lka) with a negative outlook, pointing to asset quality pressures and thinner buffers.

Fitch’s update also highlights a divergence between the strength of leading corporates and the sovereign’s fragile external position. The sovereign rating stands at CCC+, with a country ceiling of B-, indicating continued constraints on cross-border risk exposure.
In contrast, blue-chip firms such as Hayleys PLC, Lion Brewery, and Melstacorp enjoy the highest AAA(lka) national ratings, supported by diversified earnings streams and market leadership.
The plantation sector continues to lag, with Kotagala Plantations stuck at CCC(lka), a reminder of deep structural challenges.
Meanwhile, Sri Lanka Telecom is on a Rating Watch Positive (RWP) at AA-(lka), signaling potential upgrades if operational improvements and balance sheet strengthening persist.

Market analysts note that while the sovereign’s credit trajectory remains tied to the success of ongoing debt restructuring and fiscal reforms, the stability of domestic banks and corporates provides a measure of reassurance to investors and creditors.

Fitch’s findings show that Sri Lankan banks and well-managed institutions with diversified income bases remain insulated to a degree from macro headwinds, a message that wouldn’t shatter confidence in Sri Lanka’s capital markets at least for the time being.
